clinical_study.brief_title: Management of Palmar Hyperhidrosis With Hydrogel-based Iontophoresis
clinical_study.official_title: Management of Palmar Hyperhidrosis With Hydrogel-based Iontophoresis

brief_summary.textblock: This small feasibility study will evaluate the use of hydrogel electrode pads (rather than tap water baths) to deliver iontophoresis treatment using a traditional iontophoresis device. Participants will treat one hand with the hydrogel-based iontophoresis device and leave the other hand untreated.

detailed_description.textblock:
Palmar hyperhidrosis affects 4.3 million Americans and results in substantial quality of life impairment. Treatment options for palmar hyperhidrosis include antiperspirants, systemic anticholinergic agents, botulinum toxin injections, and iontophoresis. Standard iontophoresis involves submerging the hands in tap water through which current is applied to the palms for 30 minutes per day up to 3 times per week. While effective, treatment adherence rates are low.
This is a small feasibility study to evaluate the use of hydrogel electrode pads (rather than tap water baths) to deliver iontophoresis treatment using a traditional iontophoresis device. Hydrogel electrode pads permit improved mobility and hand functionality during iontophoresis treatment sessions.

primary_outcome.measure: Gravimetry as a quantitative measure of palmar sweat production
primary_outcome.description: Quantification of sweat production by gravimetry will be performed at 3 office visits to quantitatively measure sweat production during the 12 day treatment phase

secondary_outcome.measure: Modified Minor's sweat testing as a qualitative measure of palmar sweat production
secondary_outcome.description: Modified Minor's starch iodine testing, done with iodine imprints on plain paper, will be performed in office and at home to qualitatively measure sweat production during the 12 day treatment phase and the 3 week follow up phase
Participants will complete a daily study diary reporting symptom severity and comments on the iontophoresis treatment

arm_group.arm_group_label: Hand A (iontophoresis) vs. Hand B (no treatment)
arm_group.description: Hand A will be treated with hydrogel electrode-based iontophoresis. Hand B will not receive treatment.

intervention.description: During the 12 day treatment period, participants will be asked to treat one hand with the hydrogel electrode-based iontophoresis device on a daily basis. Participants will also be asked to leave the other hand untreated.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age or older
- Self-reported >6 months history of hyperhidrosis
- Initial gravimetry test sweat production of >20mg/min/palm
- No antiperspirant use on the palms for 2 weeks prior to study enrollment
- No use of systemic treatments for hyperhidrosis (anticholinergics) for 4 weeks prior to study enrollment
- No use of tap water iontophoresis for 6 weeks prior to study enrollment
- No Botox injections on the palms for 6 or 10 months prior to study enrollment for prospective participants who have undergone 1 or multiple Botox treatments, respectively
- No history of cardiothoracic sympathectomy
- Able to attend 3 clinical visits during the study period
- Capable of performing sweat level testing and hydrogel-based iontophoresis treatment at home (after training)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Individuals with implanted electronic medical devices (e.g. pacemaker, implantable cardioverter/defibrillator, metal-containing intrauterine device)
- Individuals with metal implants in the extremity to be treated
- Individuals with skin defects (on the palm or forearm of the extremity to be treated) that cannot be covered by petroleum jelly
- Women who are pregnant or nursing
- Individuals on medications that interfere with neuroglandular transmission
- Individuals with active infection locally on the extremity to be treated or systemically
- Individuals with history of contact dermatitis to acrylates or iodine
- Individuals with history of systemic allergy to iodine
- Individuals with a history of ischemic heart disease, cardiac arrhythmias, epilepsy, or thyroid disease
